Hi David, 

> The literacy is actually secondary here, which is why I'm 
> willing to live with and(greaterThan(10), lessThan(20)) when 
> I have to [2].  The primary win is that the thing you're 
> trying to assert is separated from the act of asserting, so 
> that you can write:

Yes, I've been experimenting with the use of Constraints in Asserts
in a different environment - my NUnitLite project - and I see
that there are two reasons to do it.

1) Putting the thing you want to assert into a separate object
enables all kinds of reuse and extensibility and makes the 
code within the framework much simpler and clearer.

2) The "literate" aspect is that the end user can write much
more readable asserts. That part is a matter of taste, however,
and it's very easy to build more a traditional interface on top
of constraints - the reverse is harder, I found.

Here's one of my favorite NUnitLite-style tests... It's C#,
of course, but trivial to implement in Java too...

   Assert.That( arrayOfDoubles, Is.All.GreaterThan( 0.0 ) );

Charlie

Charlie
